text: a lot of pundits around the nation are
saying that I should just stand up and
say this whole thing was a mistake that
was just a boneheaded idea and I should
just admit it it was a mistake and walk
away from it and I presume that a lot of
folks would conclude that if I did that
that'd be good for me politically but
there's only one problem with that it
wouldn't be honest I in fact did what I
believed was right for the people of my
state I'm Pam belek on the health and
medical writer for The New York Times
and I covered Mitt Romney as governor of
Massachusetts I was the Massachusetts
bureau chief for The Times what is
interesting to see today is that he made
a major speech about an issue that is
certain to dog him if he does run for
president in 2012 he's trying to both
justify his attacks on President Obama's
health care plan while at the same time
defending the Massachusetts health care
plan that he engineered our plan was a
state solution to a state problem and
his is a power grab by the federal
government to put in place of
one-size-fits-all plan across the nation
this is a complicated path that he's
trying to walk here there are a lot of
very core similarities between the two
plans the way that he's trying to strike
this difference for the most part is to
say what we did in Massachusetts was
right for us but it may not be right for
every state we didn't create a
government insurance program or a
government policy that people got no no
we gave people a premium support program
where they could buy their own private
insurance of their choice and for the
poor we helped them with support I think
the challenge here for him to is to look
as though he is proud of what he's done
that he's not running away from it but
at the same time he needs to look like
he can go on the attack against Obama as
well it's pretty early obviously he
hasn't even declared his candidacy yet
but the big question will be if he does
will voters buy it
you
